column1: # VMASKMOV — Conditional SIMD Packed Loads and Stores

| Opcode                   | Instruction                 | Op/En | 64/32-bit Mode | CPUID Feature Flag | Description                                                                                        |

column3: m128 | RVM   | V/V            | AVX                | Conditionally load packed single-precision values from m128 using mask in xmm2 and store in xmm1 . |
m256 | RVM   | V/V            | AVX                | Conditionally load packed single-precision values from m256 using mask in ymm2 and store in ymm1 . |
m128 | RVM   | V/V            | AVX                | Conditionally load packed double-precision values from m128 using mask in xmm2 and store in xmm1 . |
m256 | RVM   | V/V            | AVX                | Conditionally load packed double-precision values from m256 using mask in ymm2 and store in ymm1 . |
xmm2 | MVR   | V/V            | AVX                | Conditionally store packed single-precision values from xmm2 using mask in xmm1 .                  |
ymm2 | MVR   | V/V            | AVX                | Conditionally store packed single-precision values from ymm2 using mask in ymm1 .                  |
xmm2 | MVR   | V/V            | AVX                | Conditionally store packed double-precision values from xmm2 using mask in xmm1 .                  |
ymm2 | MVR   | V/V            | AVX                | Conditionally store packed double-precision values from ymm2 using mask in ymm1 .                  |

column1: Conditionally moves packed data elements from the second source operand into the corresponding data element of the

column2: depending on the mask bits associated with each data element. The mask bits are specified in the first source operand.

column1: The mask bit for each data element is the most significant bit of that element in the first source operand. If a mask is 1
the corresponding data element is copied from the second source operand to the destination operand. If the mask is 0
corresponding data element is set to zero in the load form of these instructions
column2: and unmodified in the store form.

column1: The second source operand is a memory address for the load form of these instruction. The destination operand is a memory address for
the store form of these instructions. The other operands are both XMM registers (for VEX.128 version) or YMM registers (for VEX.256 version).
Faults occur only due to mask-bit required memory accesses that caused the faults. Faults will not occur due to referencing any memory
location if the corresponding mask bit for that memory location is 0. For example
column2: no faults will be detected if the mask bits are all zero.

column1: Unlike previous MASKMOV instructions (MASKMOVQ and MASKMOVDQU)
column2: a nontemporal hint is not applied to these instructions.

column1: Instruction behavior on alignment check reporting with mask bits of less than all 1s are the same as with mask bits of all 1s.
VMASKMOV should not be used to access memory mapped I/O and un-cached memory as the access and the ordering of the individual loads or
stores it does is implementation specific.
In cases where mask bits indicate data should not be loaded or stored paging A and D bits will be set in an implementation dependent way.

column2: A and D bits are always set for pages where data is actually loaded/stored.
the first source (the mask) is encoded in VEX.vvvv; the second source is encoded in rm_field
the first source (the mask) is encoded in VEX.vvvv; the second source register is encoded in reg_field

column1: destination memory location is encoded in rm_field.
